file_metadata.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]
file_metadata.title: The Morphological, Behavioral, and Transcriptomic Life Cycle of Anthrobots

chunks.text: Biobots have significant potential to impact discovery in biology, biomedical engineering, and biomedicine, emerging as a unique blend of biological and robotic concepts. Their relevance falls across three categories: contributing to basic evolutionary, cell, and developmental biology; serving as a sandbox for bioengineering, active matter, and synthetic morphology; and showing promise as a technology for sensing and delivery in biomedical settings. Biobots are categorized into three types: noncellular, hybrid, and fully cellular. Noncellular biobots are entirely robotic but inspired by biological forms, while hybrid biobots combine biological and inanimate components. Fully cellular biobots, like Xenobots and Anthrobots, rely solely on the inherent capacity of biological cells to adopt new forms and functions.
chunks.chunk_summary: Biobots, classified as noncellular, hybrid, or fully cellular, hold potential for biological discovery, bioengineering, and biomedicine.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Anthrobots are self-constructing, fully cellular biobots derived from human tracheal epithelia by reprogramming the development of an airway organoid. Airway organoids mimic the architecture and function of the human airway, exhibiting key properties like mucus production and ciliary beating. While organoids aim to replicate native tissue, Anthrobots demonstrate new living forms and functions not explored by evolution. They are used to create synthetic living machines and explore motility-enabled behavior, revealing plasticity and emergent features relevant to studies of behavior evolution and diverse intelligence.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots, derived from human tracheal epithelia, are fully cellular biobots that exhibit novel forms and functions unlike airway organoids, which aim to replicate native tissue.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Environmental cues guide airway organoids toward certain morphologies, particularly the topology of apicobasal polarity, which influences cilia orientation. Maintaining cell aggregates in growth media and Matrigel results in inward-facing cilia, while techniques like air-liquid interfaces, microwells, U-bottom wells, and environmental phase shifts can produce outward-facing cilia, leading to self-motility in human bronchial epithelium samples.
chunks.chunk_summary: Environmental cues, especially apicobasal polarity, influence cilia orientation in airway organoids, with various techniques inducing outward-facing cilia and self-motility.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Anthrobots, with their unique shapes and behaviors, offer an opportunity to study the form and function of a new living configuration not subject to evolutionary selection. Predicting and exploiting emergent functionality is crucial for bioengineering and regenerative medicine. Anthrobots serve as a model system to improve our ability to predict novel life functions using adult human cells, exploring plasticity in nonembryonic life forms. They are also relevant to evolutionary developmental biology and exobiology, providing insights into "life as it could be" and the plasticity of the genome.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots, as a novel living configuration, offer a model system to study emergent functionality, plasticity in adult human cells, and "life as it could be."
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This study investigates Anthrobots' life history, including formation, maturation, death, and regenerative capacity. Epigenetic clock analysis revealed age reduction in bots compared to their source cells. Transcriptome analysis showed massive alterations compared to the cells of origin, including upregulation of evolutionarily ancient genes and embryonic patterning genes. These data shed light on the natural history of this novel synthetic architecture at molecular, cellular, tissue, physiological, and behavioral levels.
chunks.chunk_summary: This study explores Anthrobots' life history, revealing age reduction, transcriptomic alterations with upregulation of ancient and embryonic genes, and insights into their natural history.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This study investigated the self-construction process of Anthrobots, tracking their growth in Matrigel over 14 days using metrics like cellular collisions, final spheroid area, and area standard deviation. Unsupervised clustering revealed three distinct growth types: dormant (no proliferation), merger expander (merging of multiple spheroids), and monoclonal expander (growth from a single cell). These classes are statistically distinct, indicating three different developmental fates for Anthrobots.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots exhibit three distinct developmental fates: dormant, merger expander, and monoclonal expander, based on their growth patterns in Matrigel.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: RNA-seq analysis of progenitor cells and day 0 Anthrobots revealed massive transcriptomic remodeling, with 8992 out of 22,518 transcripts showing significant up- or downregulation. Pathway analysis showed enrichment in "embryonic patterning" and "multicellular organism development" gene categories.  Differential expression of endoderm and mesoderm drivers, along with dorsal-ventral and anterior-posterior patterning markers, was observed, while ectoderm and left-right patterning markers remained downregulated.  This suggests activation of embryonic transcriptional programs during Anthrobot formation.
chunks.topic: Transcriptomic changes and embryonic gene expression
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots exhibit significant transcriptomic remodeling, including upregulation of embryonic patterning genes and markers of endoderm, mesoderm, dorsal-ventral, and anterior-posterior patterning.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Phylostratigraphic analysis revealed an increase in the expression of ancient genes in Anthrobots compared to progenitor cells, particularly in the "All living organisms" and "Eukaryota" evolutionary age categories. This suggests a shift toward more ancient gene expression during Anthrobot formation, in addition to the activation of embryonic transcriptional programs.
chunks.topic: Phylostratigraphic analysis and ancient gene expression
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots show increased expression of ancient genes, indicating a phylogenetic shift towards more primitive gene expression patterns.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Anthrobots undergo eversion during maturation, bringing cilia into an outward-facing orientation.  This study characterized this process through time-lapse imaging and computational analysis, revealing two distinct eversion modes: inverted budding and noninverted budding.  These modes differ in the initial orientation of cilia and the dynamics of spheroid formation, suggesting diverse mechanisms for achieving outward-facing cilia.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots exhibit two distinct eversion modes, inverted budding and noninverted budding, during maturation, leading to outward-facing cilia.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: RNA-seq analysis of day 0 and day 10 Anthrobots revealed further transcriptomic remodeling during maturation, with significant changes in genes associated with germ layer specification and body axis establishment. Upregulation of ectoderm markers and genes involved in anterior-posterior and left-right patterning was observed, indicating molecular hallmarks of embryonic development despite the adult origin of the cells.
chunks.chunk_summary: Maturing Anthrobots undergo further transcriptomic changes, including upregulation of ectoderm markers and genes involved in body axis patterning, resembling embryonic development.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Anthrobots displayed robust behavioral longevity, maintaining consistent motility levels despite structural degradation over time. Methylation aging clock analysis revealed a significant reversal of epigenetic age in Anthrobots compared to their source cells, suggesting that the morphogenesis process reduces biological age. This age reversal occurred without rejuvenation treatment or upregulation of Yamanaka factors.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots maintain motility throughout their lifespan and exhibit a reversal of epigenetic age, suggesting rejuvenation through morphogenesis.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Anthrobots demonstrated the capacity for self-repair after mechanical damage with a hypodermic needle.  Within minutes of injury, they flexed and partially returned to their original shape.  However, no further healing or complete shape recovery was observed over longer periods.  Anthrobots separated into two halves did not rejoin, indicating limitations in their regenerative capacity.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots exhibit limited self-repair capabilities after mechanical damage, with initial shape recovery but no complete regeneration.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Time-lapse imaging and analysis of Anthrobot degradation revealed a steady rate of size reduction, with larger bots living longer due to their greater initial size. This suggests that initial morphology influences Anthrobot longevity rather than a fixed lifespan for the entire population.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots degrade at a steady rate, with larger bots having a longer lifespan due to their initial size, indicating morphology's influence on longevity.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This study characterized the life stages of Anthrobots, revealing distinct self-construction paths, robust behavioral longevity, and self-repair capabilities. The transcriptomic analysis highlighted significant alterations, including embryonic gene expression and a shift towards ancient genes. The observed age reversal suggests the potential of morphogenetic processes to influence aging.  These findings have implications for bioengineering, regenerative medicine, and evolutionary developmental biology.
chunks.chunk_summary: The study's findings on Anthrobot life stages, transcriptomic changes, age reversal, and self-repair have implications for various fields, including bioengineering and evolutionary biology.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: The self-repair capacity of Anthrobots, likely an emergent feature of epithelial dynamics, makes them a potential model for healing interventions and studies of epithelial closure.  The altered transcriptome of Anthrobots, including embryonic markers and axial patterning genes, raises questions about the relationship between molecular-genetic and morphobehavioral information. Future studies using spatial transcriptomics are needed to investigate biochemical patterning in Anthrobots and other synthetic constructs.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots' self-repair and altered transcriptome offer insights into epithelial dynamics and the relationship between molecular and behavioral information, with future studies focusing on spatial transcriptomics.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Anthrobots' robust motility and steady degradation rate make them a potential platform for screening antiaging interventions and studying basal cognition. The observed age reversal, potentially induced by morphogenetic processes, suggests a research roadmap exploiting active inference frameworks to modify cells' internal models of their age. Limitations of the study include unknown metabolic profiles and factors influencing individual bot variability. Future work will characterize biomechanical and bioelectrical properties and explore the use of stimuli to guide form and function.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots offer a platform for antiaging research and cognition studies, with future work focusing on biomechanics, bioelectricity, and stimuli-guided development.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: Synthetic living constructs like Anthrobots have potential for biomedicine and organ bioengineering.  Their limited lifespan, lack of brain tissue, and derivation from patient cells address ethical concerns in organoid research.  Characterizing how adult cells reboot multicellularity and navigate transcriptional, morphological, and behavioral spaces reveals novel aspects of the cell-body relationship, with implications for evolutionary biology and the appearance of novelty.
chunks.chunk_summary: Anthrobots' unique characteristics address ethical concerns in bioengineering, offering insights into cell-body relationships and evolutionary novelty.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]

chunks.text: This section details the experimental procedures used in the study, including RNA extraction, rRNA depletion RNA sequencing, next-generation sequencing and pathway analysis, phylostratigraphic analysis, comparison with morula genes, imaging for polarity reversal, PCA clustering, DNA extraction, DNA methylation age analysis, damage experiment, imaging for degradation, and statistical analysis.
chunks.chunk_summary: The experimental section outlines the various methods employed in the study, including RNA sequencing, DNA methylation analysis, imaging techniques, and statistical analysis.
chunks.authors: ["Gizem Gumuskaya", "Nikolai Davey", "Pranjal Srivastava", "Andrew Bender", "Léo Pio-Lopez", "Douglas Hazel", "Michael Levin"]
